questions.prompt: The trigonometric FS represents a periodic signal as:
options: A) Sum of complex exponentials from −∞ to ∞
B) a₀ + Σ(a_k cos kω₀t + b_k sin kω₀t) from k=1 to ∞
questions.correctAnswer: B) a₀ + Σ(a_k cos kω₀t + b_k sin kω₀t) from k=1 to ∞
questions.explanation: The trigonometric FS uses real-valued cosines and sines instead of complex exponentials. It sums from k=1 to ∞ (not −∞), with a₀ being the DC component. Each pair (a_k, b_k) corresponds to a pair (X_k, X_{−k}) in the EFS.

questions.prompt: For a real signal, a_k relates to X_k as:
questions.explanation: a_k = X_k + X_{−k}. For real signals, X_{−k} = X_k*, so a_k = X_k + X_k* = 2Re(X_k). Similarly, b_k = j(X_k − X_k*) = −2Im(X_k).

questions.prompt: The trig FS coefficient formulas have a factor of:
questions.explanation: a_k = (2/T₀)∫x(t)cos(kω₀t)dt and b_k = (2/T₀)∫x(t)sin(kω₀t)dt. The factor 2 arises because each trig coefficient combines two EFS coefficients (at +k and −k).

questions.prompt: Two functions φ_k(t) and φ_m(t) are orthogonal if:
options: B) Their inner product is zero
C) They have the same frequency
questions.correctAnswer: B) Their inner product is zero
questions.explanation: Orthogonality means the inner product ⟨φ_k, φ_m⟩ = 0 for k ≠ m. This is the function analogue of perpendicular vectors having zero dot product.

questions.prompt: The inner product of FS basis functions e^{jkω₀t} and e^{jmω₀t} equals:
questions.explanation: (1/T₀)∫e^{j(k−m)ω₀t}dt = 0 when k≠m (integer cycles integrate to zero) and = 1 when k=m. This Kronecker delta confirms orthonormality.

questions.prompt: Why does orthogonality ensure each X_k can be found independently?
options: A) Because the basis functions don't interfere — each projection isolates one coefficient
B) Because the signal is real
C) Because the sum is finite
D) Because X_k is always real
questions.correctAnswer: A) Because the basis functions don't interfere — each projection isolates one coefficient
questions.explanation: When you project x(t) onto e^{jk₀ω₀t}, orthogonality means all other harmonics contribute zero to the integral. Only the k₀-th coefficient survives. No cross-talk = independent computation.

questions.prompt: The trigonometric FS sum ranges from:
options: C) k = 1 to +∞ (plus a separate a₀ term)
questions.correctAnswer: C) k = 1 to +∞ (plus a separate a₀ term)
questions.explanation: The trig FS pairs the +k and −k EFS terms into single cos/sin terms. So k goes from 1 to ∞, plus the separate DC term a₀ = X₀.

questions.prompt: If X₃ = 2 − j for a real signal, then a₃ =
questions.explanation: a₃ = 2Re(X₃) = 2 × 2 = 4. The real part of X₃ is 2. For real signals, a_k = 2Re(X_k) because X_{−k} = X_k*.

questions.prompt: If X₃ = 2 − j for a real signal, then b₃ =
questions.explanation: b₃ = −2Im(X₃) = −2 × (−1) = 2. The imaginary part of X₃ is −1. For real signals, b_k = −2Im(X_k).

questions.prompt: Why is the EFS preferred over the trigonometric FS in engineering?
options: A) The EFS is always real
B) The EFS provides complete magnitude and phase information in a compact complex form
C) The trig FS doesn't work for periodic signals
D) The EFS has fewer coefficients
questions.correctAnswer: B) The EFS provides complete magnitude and phase information in a compact complex form
questions.explanation: The EFS coefficient X_k = |X_k|e^{j∠X_k} directly gives magnitude and phase for each harmonic. The trig FS splits this into a_k and b_k, losing the compact representation. Properties (shift, reversal, etc.) are also cleaner in the EFS.
